elements.content: Polycarboxylate ligands are among the most important building blocks for the synthesis of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs). The ability to access these ligands in an efficient way is of key importance for future applications of MOFs. Here, we demonstrate that mono- and dinuclear clathrochelate complexes are versatile scaffolds for the preparation of polytopic carboxylate ligands. The largely inert clathrochelate complexes have a trigonal-bipyramidal shape. The synthesis of functionalized clathrochelates with two, three, four, or five carboxylic acid groups in the ligand periphery can be achieved in a few steps from simple starting materials. Apart from being easily accessible, the metalloligands display interesting characteristics for applications in metallasupramolecular chemistry and materials science: they are rigid, large (up to 2.2 nm), and robust and they can show additional functions (e.g., fluorescence or extra charge) depending on the metal ion that is present in the clathrochelate core. The utility of these new metalloligands in MOF chemistry is demonstrated by the synthesis of zinc- and zirconium-based coordination polymers. The combination of Zn­(NO3)2 with clathrochelates having two or three carboxylic acid groups gives MOFs in which the clathrochelate ligands are connected by Zn4O clusters or zinc paddlewheel links. The structures of the resulting two- and three-dimensional networks could be established by single-crystal X-ray crystallography. The reaction of carboxylic acid functionalized clathrochelates with ZrCl4 gives amorphous powders that display permanent porosity after solvent removal.

elements.content: Carboxylic acid functionalized ligands are of paramount importance in supramolecular chemistry, most notably in the preparation of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs). Since the pioneering discovery of compounds such as MOF-5 by Yaghi and co-workers and HKUST-1 by the group of Williams, the number of reported MOF structures continues to grow exponentially.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Carboxylic acid functionalized ligands are of paramount importance in supramolecular chemistry, most notably in the preparation of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs). Since the pioneering discovery of compounds such as MOF-5 by Yaghi and co-workers and HKUST-1 by the group of Williams, the number of reported MOF structures continues to grow exponentially.

elements.content: The development of MOF chemistry has, in part, been driven by the variety of ligands employed in the preparation of these materials. The concept of reticular chemistry, along with a range of well-established synthetic techniques for MOF preparation, has enabled the strategic incorporation of increasingly elaborate ligands into MOFs, the properties and structural characteristics of which are determined by the ligands themselves. This powerful, modular means to prepare bespoke materials in a targeted manner is exemplified by MOF-5 and its isoreticular analogues, which have been constructed from a wide range of ditopic carboxylic acid ligands such as those based on extended oligo­(phenylenes) and terephthalic acid derivatives and even metal complexes (metalloligands). The incorporation of functional moieties, including photoactive groups, catalytically active metal centers, or simple organic functional groups, into carboxylic acid based MOF building blocks has facilitated the preparation of materials with new and interesting properties.
elements.clean_text: The development of MOF chemistry has, in part, been driven by the variety of ligands employed in the preparation of these materials. The concept of reticular chemistry, along with a range of well-established synthetic techniques for MOF preparation, has enabled the strategic incorporation of increasingly elaborate ligands into MOFs, the properties and structural characteristics of which are determined by the ligands themselves. This powerful, modular means to prepare bespoke materials in a targeted manner is exemplified by MOF-5 and its isoreticular analogues, which have been constructed from a wide range of ditopic carboxylic acid ligands such as those based on extended oligo(phenylenes) and terephthalic acid derivatives and even metal complexes (metalloligands). The incorporation of functional moieties, including photoactive groups, catalytically active metal centers, or simple organic functional groups, into carboxylic acid based MOF building blocks has facilitated the preparation of materials with new and interesting properties.

elements.content: Another ligand property that has received a significant amount of attention in recent times is size. The preparation of longer or expanded building blocks has enabled MOFs with greater internal void volumes, cavity dimensions, and surface areas to be made. Consequently, these materials are, for example, capable of the uptake of larger guest species or greater volumes of adsorbed gas. Again, reticular synthesis has encouraged the design of numerous expanded MOF structures based on well-known network topologies, but common setbacks encountered during research into these materials include the observation of extensive network interpenetration. Other obstacles are the synthetic efforts and costs associated with the preparation of large ligands. This point is exemplified by the work of the groups of Yaghi and Stoddart, who developed a series of ditopic linear α-hydroxycarboxylic acid ligands up to 5 nm in length. These building blocks were subsequently incorporated into a range of isostructural MOFs (the IRMOF-74 series), which possessed interior channel apertures of up to 98 Å. Synthesis of the longest ligand employed in this study required eight steps and gave an overall yield of 14%.

elements.content: Herein, we report a means to efficiently prepare large di-, tri-, tetra-, and pentatopic carboxylic acid ligands in a few steps from simple starting materials. Our ligands consist of trigonal-bipyramidal clathrochelate complexes to which carboxylic acid groups may be appended in a modular manner (). To demonstrate the utility of these metalloligands in structural supramolecular chemistry, we prepared a series of new coordination polymers, in which the clathrochelates are linked by zinc or zirconium clusters to give two- or three-dimensional (2D or 3D) networks.

To demonstrate the utility of these metalloligands in structural supramolecular chemistry, we prepared a series of new coordination polymers, in which the clathrochelates are linked by zinc or zirconium clusters to give two- or three-dimensional (2D or 3D) networks.

elements.content: In 2006, the group of Chaudhuri reported the synthesis and structural characterization of a dinuclear manganese­(II) clathrochelate complex with bridging phenolatodioximato ligands and capping methylboronate esters. We recently showed that it is possible to construct 4,4′-bipyridyl ligands based on similar dinuclear complexes by replacing the terminal methylboronate esters with pyridylboronate esters. A unique feature of these pyridyl-capped metalloligands is their negative charge, which may bestow supramolecular assemblies with extra stability.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis of the Clathrochelates

In 2006, the group of Chaudhuri reported the synthesis and structural characterization of a dinuclear manganese(II) clathrochelate complex with bridging phenolatodioximato ligands and capping methylboronate esters. We recently showed that it is possible to construct 4,4'-bipyridyl ligands based on similar dinuclear complexes by replacing the terminal methylboronate esters with pyridylboronate esters. A unique feature of these pyridyl-capped metalloligands is their negative charge, which may bestow supramolecular assemblies with extra stability.

elements.content: We hypothesized that dinuclear clathrochelates could also be used as scaffolds for the preparation of new polycarboxylate ligands, which should represent highly interesting building blocks for MOF chemistry. Indeed, anionic manganese­(II) tris­(dioximato) complexes (M2+ = Co, Zn) with two appended carboxylic acid groups were obtained by the reaction of 4-carboxyphenylboronic acid, 2,6-diformyl-4-tert-butylphenol dioxime (L 1 ), or 2,6-diformyl-4-bromophenol dioxime (L 2 ) and the appropriate metal salt (Zn­(OTf)2 or [Co­(H2O)6]­(NO3)2) in a mixture of methanol and ethanol (). It should be noted that the boronic acid is commercially available, and the dioximes can be prepared easily from the corresponding dialdehydes. In contrast to the synthesis of pyridyl-capped clathrochelates reported previously, the presence of a base was required for insertion of the third phenolatodioximato ligand. Tetraethylammonium hydroxide was chosen for this purpose because the NEt4 + cation enhances the solubility of the final complexes. The products 1–4 precipitated from solution as amorphous solids upon concentration of the mother liquor. The high yields of 74–92% indicate that the CO2H functions on the boronic acid do not interfere with formation of the dinuclear clathrochelate core, even though Zn2+ and Co2+ ions are known to bind carboxylate ligands. The anionic clathrochelates 1–4 are well soluble in polar aprotic solvents such as N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), dimethylacetamide (DMA), and dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO).

The anionic clathrochelates 1-4 are well soluble in polar aprotic solvents such as N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), dimethylacetamide (DMA), and dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO).

elements.content: Clathrochelates 1–4 were analyzed by high-resolution mass spectrometry, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, and, for the diamagnetic complexes 1 and 3, NMR spectroscopy. As expected, only one set of signals was observed for the phenolatodioximato ligands, revealing the pseudo-C 3 symmetry of the complexes. Single-crystal X-ray structural analysis of 2 revealed the presence of the expected dinuclear clathrochelate core with terminal carboxylic acid groups ().

elements.content: The two Co2+ ions in complex 2 are coordinated in a trigonal-prismatic fashion by three nitrogen and three oxygen atoms. The two carbon atoms of the terminal CO2H groups are 21 Å apart from each other. This length is notably far from the 50 Å of the IRMOF-74-XI ligand, but the synthetic efforts cannot be confronted. The clathrochelate 2 is, however, comparable to ditopic linkers having up to five phenylene spacers, such as ligand V (about 22 Å) in IRMOF-74-V, or slightly larger than trans-bis­(carboxylate)­tetraarylporphyrins, such as H4DCPMes2P in PIZA-4, or ditopic ligands with four aryl ring spacers. In solution, the zinc complexes 1 and 3 display pseudo-C 3 symmetry. In the solid state, one can observe a small deviation from this “ideal” geometry, with angles between the planes of the three lateral oximato ligands of 116.90°, 119.95°, and 123.13° (, bottom).
elements.clean_text: The two Co2+ ions in complex 2 are coordinated in a trigonal-prismatic fashion by three nitrogen and three oxygen atoms. The two carbon atoms of the terminal CO2H groups are 21 Å apart from each other. This length is notably far from the 50 Å of the IRMOF-74-XI ligand, but the synthetic efforts cannot be confronted. The clathrochelate 2 is, however, comparable to ditopic linkers having up to five phenylene spacers, such as ligand V (about 22 Å) in IRMOF-74-V, or slightly larger than trans-bis(carboxylate)tetraarylporphyrins, such as H4DCPMes2P in PIZA-4, or ditopic ligands with four aryl ring spacers. In solution, the zinc complexes 1 and 3 display pseudo-C 3 symmetry. In the solid state, one can observe a small deviation from this "ideal" geometry, with angles between the planes of the three lateral oximato ligands of 116.90°, 119.95°, and 123.13° (, bottom).

elements.content: A synthetic strategy similar to that employed for 1–4 was used to prepare the clathrochelate complex 5 featuring four carboxylic acid functions attached to the terminal arylboronate ester groups (). The clathrochelate 5 was obtained as a fully protonated tetraethylammonium salt in 44% yield and characterized by high-resolution mass spectrometry, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, and NMR spectroscopy.

elements.content: In addition to the anionic, dinuclear clathrochelates presented above, we prepared mononuclear clathrochelate complexes with terminal CO2H groups (6–11). Synthesis of these complexes was achieved by the reaction of anhydrous FeCl2 with commercial dioximes and 3- or 4-carboxyphenylboronic acid, respectively (). The ditopic complexes 6 and 8 are known, but applications in supramolecular chemistry have not been reported. We prepared the novel, less sterically bulky analogues 7 and 9 using dimethylglyoxime. A closely related approach was subsequently employed in the synthesis of tetratopic clathrochelates 10 and 11. All complexes were characterized by high-resolution mass spectrometry and NMR spectroscopy. In contrast to the ionic compounds 1–5, the difunctional clathrochelates 6–9 are soluble in organic solvents such as dichloromethane, with the dimethylglyoxime-derived complexes 7 and 9 being slightly less soluble than the nioxime-derived complexes 6 and 8 (nioxime = 1,2-cyclohexanedione dioxime). The tetratopic clathrochelates 10 and 11 are soluble in polar aprotic solvents, such as DMSO and DMF.

The two carbon atoms of the terminal CO2H groups in complex 8 are 17.921(2) Å apart from each other.

elements.content: The clathrochelate complexes 1–11 feature either two or four CO2H groups, which were introduced during the synthesis by using a functionalized arylboronic acid. The oximato ligands occupy lateral positions with respect to the axis defined by the two boron atoms. By using different oximato ligands, we have demonstrated that it is possible to change the size and solubility of the metalloligands independently from the function-defining boronic acid.

By using different oximato ligands, we have demonstrated that it is possible to change the size and solubility of the metalloligands independently from the function-defining boronic acid.

elements.content: We envisioned that it should also be possible to use the oximato ligands to introduce additional CO2H groups, thereby broadening the variety and, hence, potential applications of clathrochelate-based metalloligands. This goal was accomplished through synthesis of the CO2H-functionalized dioximato ligand L 3 . Suzuki–Miyaura coupling of 4-carboxy­phenylboronic acid and 2,6-diformyl-4-bromophenol in the presence of Pd2(dba)3 and Buchwald’s SPhos ligand in n-BuOH afforded the crude diformylphenol intermediate, which was converted to its corresponding dioxime L 3 by treatment with hydroxylamine hydrochloride ().

Suzuki-Miyaura coupling of 4-carboxyphenylboronic acid and 2,6-diformyl-4-bromophenol in the presence of Pd2(dba)3 and Buchwald's SPhos ligand in n-BuOH afforded the crude diformylphenol intermediate, which was converted to its corresponding dioxime L  3  by treatment with hydroxylamine hydrochloride ().

elements.content: The new ligand L 3 was subsequently used for synthesis of the clathrochelates 12 and 13 (). These complexes feature three CO2H groups in the equatorial position and two bromine atoms in the axial position. On the basis of simple molecular modeling considerations, we expect a distance of approximately 18.6 Å between the carbon atoms of the carboxylic acid groups. Consequently, these trigonal metalloligands are significantly larger than the commonly employed 1,3,5-tris­(4-carboxyphenyl)­benzene ligand (C···C = 12.55 Å). The bromine atoms were introduced because they were found to slightly improve the solubility of the clathrochelates.

elements.content: By using ligand L 3 in combination with the capping agent 4-carboxyphenylboronic acid, we obtained the pentatopic clathrochelate ligands 14 and 15 (). To date, very few examples of 5-fold-coordinating ligands have been studied, and our clathrochelates are, to the best of our knowledge, the largest such ligands ever reported.

To date, very few examples of 5-fold-coordinating ligands have been studied, and our clathrochelates are, to the best of our knowledge, the largest such ligands ever reported.

elements.content: In the discussion so far, we have mainly focused on the size and geometry of the new metalloligands. However, there are also other properties that are worth noting. The zinc-based clathrochelates 1, 3, 5, 12, and 14 are all luminescent, with emission maxima at around 450 nm (1, 445 nm, λex = 325 nm; 3, 452 nm, λex = 335 nm; 5, 445 nm, λex = 335 nm; 12, 457 nm, λex = 335 nm; 14, 445 nm, λex = 335 nm, in DMF/DMSO; Figures S37 and S38). Because of the inert character of the Zn2+ ions, the luminescence can be assigned to intraligand and/or ligand-to-ligand charge-transfer emissions. The dinuclear cobalt complexes are not emissive, presumably because of quenching by the paramagnetic metal ions. The magnetic properties of the cobalt clathrochelates were not studied in detail; however, for complexes 2 and 4, we determined effective magnetic moments (μeff) of 5.37 and 5.81 μB, respectively, by using the Evans method. We also stress the intrinsic charge displayed by the dinuclear zinc- and cobalt-containing clathrochelates. This additional negative charge represents a fundamental difference compared to standard carboxylic acid ligands, which only become charged after deprotonation of the CO2H groups.

Because of the inert character of the Zn2+ ions, the luminescence can be assigned to intraligand and/or ligand-to-ligand charge-transfer emissions. The dinuclear cobalt complexes are not emissive, presumably because of quenching by the paramagnetic metal ions. The magnetic properties of the cobalt clathrochelates were not studied in detail; however, for complexes 2 and 4, we determined effective magnetic moments (μeff) of 5.37 and 5.81 μB, respectively, by using the Evans method. We also stress the intrinsic charge displayed by the dinuclear zinc- and cobalt-containing clathrochelates. This additional negative charge represents a fundamental difference compared to standard carboxylic acid ligands, which only become charged after deprotonation of the CO2H groups.

elements.content: Having shown that carboxylic acid functionalized clathrochelate complexes can be synthesized in one pot from simple and readily available starting materials, we examined applications as supramolecular building blocks. On the basis of their structures, it was not established that the clathrochelate core would be compatible with the relatively harsh conditions employed for MOF syntheses. The lateral side groups of the oximes were also a challenging part because it was difficult to estimate whether the steric bulk from adjacent clathrochelates was or was not a pitfall for formation of the rectangular coordination pattern found in many MOFs. On the other hand, the lateral groups could be found as a virtue, preventing interpenetration of the networks. The effect of the intrinsic negative charge shared by the bimetallic clathrochelates was also an unknown parameter to take into account.
elements.clean_text:
Utilization as Metalloligands in MOFs

Having shown that carboxylic acid functionalized clathrochelate complexes can be synthesized in one pot from simple and readily available starting materials, we examined applications as supramolecular building blocks. On the basis of their structures, it was not established that the clathrochelate core would be compatible with the relatively harsh conditions employed for MOF syntheses. The lateral side groups of the oximes were also a challenging part because it was difficult to estimate whether the steric bulk from adjacent clathrochelates was or was not a pitfall for formation of the rectangular coordination pattern found in many MOFs. On the other hand, the lateral groups could be found as a virtue, preventing interpenetration of the networks. The effect of the intrinsic negative charge shared by the bimetallic clathrochelates was also an unknown parameter to take into account.

elements.content: In order to demonstrate that our clathrochelate-based poly­(carboxylic acid)­s are suitable for incorporation into MOFs, we targeted the syntheses of two representative coordination polymer classes, the first one sharing MOF-5 topology and the second one related to zirconium-based MOFs (Zr-MOFs). MOF-5 is among the most extensively studied porous materials since its discovery in 1999, and given the vast range of isostructural MOF-5 analogues that have been reported, along with the interesting functional properties possessed by many of these materials, this framework structure was considered to be an ideal initial candidate for the incorporation of carboxylic acid functionalized clathrochelate complexes into MOFs. The solvothermal reaction of ditopic ligands 1, 2, and 4 and [Zn­(H2O)6]­(NO3)2 in a mixture of DMF and a chlorinated aromatic solvent (chlorobenzene, 1,2-dichlorobenzene, or 1,2,4-trichlorobenzene) or DEF at 120 °C resulted in the formation of single crystals upon heating ().

MOF-5 is among the most extensively studied porous materials since its discovery in 1999, and given the vast range of isostructural MOF-5 analogues that have been reported, along with the interesting functional properties possessed by many of these materials, this framework structure was considered to be an ideal initial candidate for the incorporation of carboxylic acid functionalized clathrochelate complexes into MOFs. The solvothermal reaction of ditopic ligands 1, 2, and 4 and [Zn(H2O)6](NO3)2 in a mixture of DMF and a chlorinated aromatic solvent (chlorobenzene, 1,2-dichlorobenzene, or 1,2,4-trichlorobenzene) or DEF at 120 °C resulted in the formation of single crystals upon heating ().

elements.content: Single crystals suitable for X-ray structural analysis were obtained for all of the different solvent systems. Because of weak diffraction and the high disorder observed in the crystals, the key to a successful refinement was utilization of stereochemical restraints for the clathrochelate ligands within the MOFs 16–20, which were generated by the GRADE program. This macromolecular refinement technique has been adapted to be used in the program SHELXL. We have already used this methodology for other clathrochelate-based structures, and it was found to drastically increase the robustness of the refinement, especially when combined with the new rigid bond restraint in SHELXL (RIGU). The program ShelXle, which supports the macromolecular residue grouping, was used as a GUI. The DSR program was employed to semiautomatically model disordered moieties.

elements.content: Crystallographic analysis of the MOF 16 revealed a topology identical with that of MOF-5 and the IRMOF-n series. The framework is composed of clathrochelate complexes ligated to Zn4O clusters by their carboxylate groups (). These clusters are composed of four tetrahedral Zn2+ cations and a central μ4-oxygen atom.

elements.content: Unlike MOF-5, where each Zn4O node adopts an octahedral geometry with respect to the organic linkers, 16 showed a slightly distorted geometry. Indeed, the zinc secondary building units (SBUs) are linked together by the deprotonated dicarboxylic acid ligands in a trigonal-antiprismatic fashion. The central oxygen atoms from adjacent zinc SBUs are separated by a distance of 27.750(5) Å; the angles between the axis of the clathrochelate ligands (as defined by the central μ4-oxygen atoms of the Zn4O nodes) are 71° and 109° for cis pairs of clathrochelates, respectively, to be compared to the average 90° angle in the IRMOF-n series. Somewhat surprisingly, the network is 2-fold-interpenetrated (Figure S46). Such an interpenetration has frequently been observed for MOF-5 assemblies constructed from long carboxylate ligands, but we had anticipated that the steric bulk of the equatorial tert-butyl groups of the phenolatodioximato ligands within 1 might prevent such an interpenetration. A unique feature of 16 compared to standard MOF-5-type structures is the fact that the network is negatively charged (the bridging carboxylate ligands display a charge of 3−). The charge is compensated for by NEt4 + cations, which are found in the voids of the structure.

elements.content: 'Whereas the structures of the MOFs 18 and 19 are very similar to what was observed for 16, the MOF 17 revealed a different behavior. The 3D framework is likewise composed of clathrochelate metalloligands connected to Zn4O clusters (). However, three of the Zn2+ cations adopt a classical tetrahedral geometry, while the fourth is six-coordinate and octahedral.

elements.content: Several groups have studied the exchange of one tetrahedral Zn2+ ion within a Zn4O SBU with another, octahedral metal ion, but reports of the formation of unusual geometries for one of the Zn2+ ions are scarce. Notably, the group of Gao reported in 2010 the synthesis of a rare Kagomé topology with a five-coordinate trigonal-bipyramidal geometry for one of the Zn2+ ions and an octahedral geometry for another after binding of two DMSO molecules. Within the Zn4O clusters of 17, three Zn2+ ions (Zn1, Zn2, and Zn3) are located in tetrahedral environments, with each metal ion being coordinated by three carboxylate oxygen atoms from different clathrochelate ligands and the μ4-oxygen atom in the center of the cluster (, bottom). The remaining zinc atom (Zn4) adopts an unusual octahedral geometry, coordinated by the central μ4-oxygen atom, three carboxylate oxygen atoms, and two extra oxygen atoms that were attributed to one DMF molecule and one water molecule, with the latter coming most likely from the hydrated zinc salt used in the synthesis of MOFs. It should be noted that the unusual SBU can be found in the bulk material of 17, as evidenced by powder XRD, but because of the poor quality of the diffraction data, we cannot exclude the presence of small amounts of a different phase (Figure S56).

The remaining zinc atom (Zn4) adopts an unusual octahedral geometry, coordinated by the central μ4-oxygen atom, three carboxylate oxygen atoms, and two extra oxygen atoms that were attributed to one DMF molecule and one water molecule, with the latter coming most likely from the hydrated zinc salt used in the synthesis of MOFs. elements.content: The presence of one octahedral Zn2+ ion within the Zn4O cluster significantly affects the structure of the MOF 17. In contrast to the IRMOF-n series or the MOF 16, where the tetranuclear cluster connects three collinear pairs of bis­(carboxylate) ligands, the MOF 17 contains one pair of clathrochelate ligands, the axes of which are tilted with respect to each other. The angles between opposite pairs of clathrochelate ligands are 180°, 180°, and 135°. The latter results in distortion of the framework structure, which displays a zigzag shape along the crystallographic c axis (, top). The central μ4-oxygen atoms of adjacent Zn4O SBUs are separated by distances of 27.471(2) and 27.894(1) Å, with the latter being only slightly longer than that for 16. Coordination of one DMF molecule to one of the Zn2+ ions in the tetranuclear cluster was only observed for the MOF 17, whereas 16, 18, and 19 did not feature this asymmetric SBU. A convincing rationale for formation of this octahedral Zn2+ ion has not yet been formulated.

elements.content: We also investigated the formation of network structures using the metalloligand 4 having less sterically demanding phenolatodioximato ligands (bromo instead of tert-butyl). The solvothermal treatment of 4 with Zn­(NO3)2(H2O)6 in a DMF/DEF mixture at 120 °C resulted in the formation of orange cubic single crystals of the MOF 20 (). Structural analysis of 20 revealed minor differences compared to 17–19 (Figures S52 and S53). Considerably reducing the steric bulk by exchanging the tert-butyl side chains with a bromo substituent did not influence the network interpenetration (2-fold). The channels found in 20 are occupied by NEt4 + cations; however, the global disorder of the crystal did not allow us to precisely locate its alkyl chains.

elements.content: In order to assess the gas sorption properties of the zinc-based MOFs (Zn-MOFs) 17–20, N2 physisorption experiments were performed. Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area measurements (N2, 77 K) after activation of the crystals by heating at 150 °C under dynamic vacuum gave only low values (16, 98 m2/g; 17, 125 m2/g; 18, 58 m2/g; 19, 26 m2/g; 20, 32 m2/g). The low N2 adsorption is likely due to the 2-fold interpenetration of the networks and due to the presence of NEt4 + cations, resulting in a drastically reduced accessible void volume. Digestion 1H NMR of 16–20 after the gas sorption measurement revealed the presence of residual DMF despite the activation process (Figures S27–S31). Digestion 1H NMR experiments also unambiguously confirmed the presence of NEt4 + cations within the network pores. Attempts to activate the crystals by solvent exchange with methanol or acetone gave even lower values for the BET measurements because of collapse of the networks during the exchange process. The sensitivity of the network structure was confirmed by powder XRD analyses of 16 and 18–20, which revealed complete loss of crystallinity upon drying of the materials.

The low N2 adsorption is likely due to the 2-fold interpenetration of the networks and due to the presence of NEt4 + cations, resulting in a drastically reduced accessible void volume. elements.content: Having shown that bimetallic clathrochelates can be incorporated in the MOF structures, we attempted similar syntheses using iron­(II) tris­(dioxime) clathrochelate (8). However, in combination with [Zn­(H2O)6]­(NO3)2 in DMA, we observed formation of the 2D-layered coordination polymer 21 (). The coordination polymer 21 is comprised of 2D sheets, in which doubly deprotonated molecules of 8 bridge between Zn2+ paddlewheel SBUs (). DMA molecules are coordinated to the apical positions of the Zn2+ ions. Each layer of 21 is identical in its composition and orientation, but rather than eclipsing one another when viewed perpendicularly to the plane of a single Zn­(8) sheet, the layers are offset by 7.76 Å. This structural feature is likely due to the steric clash of not only apical DMA molecules bound to zinc but also the bulky cyclohexyl substituents of the clathrochelate complexes themselves. Despite the offset packing within 21, one-dimensioanl channels, filled with disordered solvent molecules in the crystal, permeate the material. The aperture and volume of these channels are determined by the steric bulk of the cyclohexyl groups of the clathrochelate oxime substituents. Removal of the guest solvent molecules led to total collapse of the coordination network structure, resulting in a nonporous material.

elements.content: We also studied the formation of networks using our tritopic clathrochelate 12. The reaction of 12 with [Zn­(H2O)6]­(NO3)2 in a mixture of DMF and DMSO resulted in the formation of transparent block-shaped crystals of 22 (). Crystallographic analysis of 22 showed a 3D network in which all carboxylic acid units of 12 are coordinated to a Zn4O cluster (). As was observed for 17, the zinc cluster is composed of three tetrahedral and one octahedral Zn2+ ion (shown as blue and green polyhedra, respectively). The octahedral ion is coordinated by the central μ4-oxygen atom, three oxygen atoms from the deprotonated carboxylate groups, and two DMSO molecules. Several examples of tritopic carboxylate ligands connected by Zn4O clusters have been reported so far, but to the best of our knowledge, the presence of one octahedral zinc within the Zn4O cluster is unprecedented. Consequently, 22 displays a connectivity slightly different from that observed for MOFs constructed from tritopic carboxylate ligands. The network of 22 is 2-fold-interpenetrated and anionic and, hence, contains NEt4 + cations, as verified by digestion NMR (Figure S32), leading to a material with very low porosity (BET surface area of 21 m2/g).

elements.content: In order to assess the versatility of our clathrochelates in the synthesis of other types of MOF, we turned to Zr-MOFs. In 2008, Lillerud and co-workers reported the synthesis of a new inorganic building unit, namely, Zr6O4(OH)4(CO2)12. The solvothermal reaction between ZrCl4 and terephthalic acic or terphenyldicarboxylic acid resulted in the formation of porous materials with specific surface areas of 1187 and 4170 m2/g, which were designated as UiO-66 and UiO-68, respectively. Subsequent work has shown that the 12-fold-coordinated cluster Zr6O4(OH)4(CO2)12 can be reduced to 8-fold and even 6-fold SBUs by using appropriate polycarboxylate ligands. MOFs based on zirconium clusters have attracted a lot of attention because these materials can display very high chemical stability. Capitalizing on this characteristic, numerous applications have emerged over the last years, including the utilization of transition-metal functionalized Zr-MOFs as catalysts for organic syntheses or the utilization of Zr-MOFs for the hydrolytic decontamination of chemical warfare agents.

elements.content: In order to examine if our clathrochelate-based metalloligands could be used to synthesize Zr-MOFs, we investigated the reaction of ditopic complexes 2 and 4 with ZrCl4 in DMF. Initial worries that the clathrochelates would not withstand the rather harsh reaction conditions (120 °C, the presence of the strong Lewis acid ZrCl4) were not justified: after 3 days, we were able to obtain the Zr-MOFs 23 and 24 in the form of orange powders in good yields ().

elements.content: Powder XRD analyses of 23 and 24 showed that the materials were poorly- (24; Figure S57) or non-crystalline (23). Attempts to increase the crystallinity by using modulators such as benzoic or acetic acid were, unfortunately, not successful. In view of the poorly resolved powder XRD spectra, we can only speculate about the type of zirconium cluster that is present in 23 and 24. On the basis of steric considerations, even the 12-fold-coordinated Zr6 cluster seems possible despite the substantial lateral size of the metalloligand 2 (Figure S55). Interestingly, 23 and 24 appear to be neutral network structures because the NMR spectra of digested samples do not show signals corresponding to the NEt4 + cations (Figures S33 and S34). The necessary charge compensation could be accomplished by exchange of a hydroxide for a water ligand on the zirconium cluster.

elements.content: Encouraged by the successful synthesis of 23 and 24, we subsequently investigated utilization of the tri- and pentatopic metalloligands 13 and 15. The observations were similar to those before: after 3 days (DMF, 120 °C), we were able to collect orange, amorphous powders (25 and 26; ). The absence of NEt4 + cations in 25 and 26 was again confirmed by digestion experiments.

elements.content: In contrast to the Zn-MOFs 16–22, the Zr-MOFs were all found to display substantial permanent porosity after removal of the solvent by heating at 150 °C under dynamic vacuum. BET (N2, 77 K) measurements revealed specific surface areas of 410 m2/g (23), 955 m2/g (24), 535 m2/g (25), and 546 m2/g (26). It is worth noting that the surface area of 24 is more than twice that of 23. Both 23 and 24 are based on the same type of ditopic metalloligand, differing only in terms of the equatorial group R (bromo vs tert-butyl). This result suggests that it is possible to use the lateral oximato ligands for modulating the porosity of the MOFs. CO2 (273 K) physisorption experiments revealed high capacities for all Zr-MOFs, with the MOF 24 being able to take up 85 cm3/g at 1 bar. This value is slightly higher than that observed for UiO-66 derivatives.

elements.content: Mono- and dinuclear clathrochelate complexes with up to five pendent carboxylic acid groups have been synthesized by metal-templated reactions using easily accessible starting materials. These rigid and robust complexes represent interesting metalloligands for applications in metallasupramolecular chemistry and materials science. The carboxylic acid functions are oriented in a divergent fashion, with well-defined coordinate vectors. In terms of size, the clathrochelates are comparable to carboxylic acid functionalized porphyrin ligands, which have found numerous applications in the past. A unique feature of our new metalloligands is their trigonal-bipyramidal geometry. Such a geometry is difficult to access with purely organic scaffolds.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Mono- and dinuclear clathrochelate complexes with up to five pendent carboxylic acid groups have been synthesized by metal-templated reactions using easily accessible starting materials. These rigid and robust complexes represent interesting metalloligands for applications in metallasupramolecular chemistry and materials science. The carboxylic acid functions are oriented in a divergent fashion, with well-defined coordinate vectors. In terms of size, the clathrochelates are comparable to carboxylic acid functionalized porphyrin ligands, which have found numerous applications in the past. A unique feature of our new metalloligands is their trigonal-bipyramidal geometry. Such a geometry is difficult to access with purely organic scaffolds.

elements.content: To demonstrate the utility of carboxylic acid functionalized clathrochelates in MOF chemistry, we synthesized 2D and 3D network structures with zinc or zirconium clusters as SBUs. These preliminary results show that the metalloligands are compatible with the reaction conditions employed for MOF synthesis and that the steric bulk of the clathrochelates is not detrimental to the coordination of multiple metalloligands to one SBU. One should also note that the thermal and chemical stability of the clathrochelates is sufficient for many potential applications.

One should also note that the thermal and chemical stability of the clathrochelates is sufficient for many potential applications.

cln_elements.content:
In order to assess the gas sorption properties of the zinc-based MOFs (Zn-MOFs) 17–20, N2 physisorption experiments were performed. Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area measurements (N2, 77 K) after activation of the crystals by heating at 150 °C under dynamic vacuum gave only low values (16, 98 m2/g; 17, 125 m2/g; 18, 58 m2/g; 19, 26 m2/g; 20, 32 m2/g). The low N2 adsorption is likely due to the 2-fold interpenetration of the networks and due to the presence of NEt4 + cations, resulting in a drastically reduced accessible void volume. Digestion 1H NMR of 16–20 after the gas sorption measurement revealed the presence of residual DMF despite the activation process (Figures S27–S31). Digestion 1H NMR experiments also unambiguously confirmed the presence of NEt4 + cations within the network pores. Attempts to activate the crystals by solvent exchange with methanol or acetone gave even lower values for the BET measurements because of collapse of the networks during the exchange process. The sensitivity of the network structure was confirmed by powder XRD analyses of 16 and 18–20, which revealed complete loss of crystallinity upon drying of the materials.

We also studied the formation of networks using our tritopic clathrochelate 12. The reaction of 12 with [Zn­(H2O)6]­(NO3)2 in a mixture of DMF and DMSO resulted in the formation of transparent block-shaped crystals of 22 (). Crystallographic analysis of 22 showed a 3D network in which all carboxylic acid units of 12 are coordinated to a Zn4O cluster (). As was observed for 17, the zinc cluster is composed of three tetrahedral and one octahedral Zn2+ ion (shown as blue and green polyhedra, respectively). The octahedral ion is coordinated by the central μ4-oxygen atom, three oxygen atoms from the deprotonated carboxylate groups, and two DMSO molecules. Several examples of tritopic carboxylate ligands connected by Zn4O clusters have been reported so far, but to the best of our knowledge, the presence of one octahedral zinc within the Zn4O cluster is unprecedented. Consequently, 22 displays a connectivity slightly different from that observed for MOFs constructed from tritopic carboxylate ligands. The network of 22 is 2-fold-interpenetrated and anionic and, hence, contains NEt4 + cations, as verified by digestion NMR (Figure S32), leading to a material with very low porosity (BET surface area of 21 m2/g).

In order to assess the versatility of our clathrochelates in the synthesis of other types of MOF, we turned to Zr-MOFs. In 2008, Lillerud and co-workers reported the synthesis of a new inorganic building unit, namely, Zr6O4(OH)4(CO2)12. The solvothermal reaction between ZrCl4 and terephthalic acic or terphenyldicarboxylic acid resulted in the formation of porous materials with specific surface areas of 1187 and 4170 m2/g, which were designated as UiO-66 and UiO-68, respectively. Subsequent work has shown that the 12-fold-coordinated cluster Zr6O4(OH)4(CO2)12 can be reduced to 8-fold and even 6-fold SBUs by using appropriate polycarboxylate ligands. MOFs based on zirconium clusters have attracted a lot of attention because these materials can display very high chemical stability. Capitalizing on this characteristic, numerous applications have emerged over the last years, including the utilization of transition-metal functionalized Zr-MOFs as catalysts for organic syntheses or the utilization of Zr-MOFs for the hydrolytic decontamination of chemical warfare agents.

In contrast to the Zn-MOFs 16–22, the Zr-MOFs were all found to display substantial permanent porosity after removal of the solvent by heating at 150 °C under dynamic vacuum. BET (N2, 77 K) measurements revealed specific surface areas of 410 m2/g (23), 955 m2/g (24), 535 m2/g (25), and 546 m2/g (26). It is worth noting that the surface area of 24 is more than twice that of 23. Both 23 and 24 are based on the same type of ditopic metalloligand, differing only in terms of the equatorial group R (bromo vs tert-butyl). This result suggests that it is possible to use the lateral oximato ligands for modulating the porosity of the MOFs. CO2 (273 K) physisorption experiments revealed high capacities for all Zr-MOFs, with the MOF 24 being able to take up 85 cm3/g at 1 bar. This value is slightly higher than that observed for UiO-66 derivatives.
